item.title: Our_first_pygame_6
item.description: A lot has happened. I decided to continue with app development without the sprites for now. I fixed input and movement as they were not doing what I wanted the way I wanted. The input change was easy. Mostly a fix from moving the code to a class and being able to access the input. I need to add last key pressed and key order (key queue), yes and I could do more.

item.title: Hugo site on github
item.description: Steps we follow create 2 github repositories. name.github.io and hugoblog Get Hugo and git Create the hugo site locally init git for hugoblog and add public as a git submodule Add a theme (possibly as a submodule) go to the example site folder and copy the files if necessary, rename config.toml to hugo.toml if the posts use the yaml (—) format not toml add a posts archetype can create your first post ## Run hugo server and take a look check existing content remove or replace default content Test and fix site Publish Create the github repositories I have a post on using GIT.

item.title: Our first pygame - Sprites - part 5
item.description: CODE REPOSITORY branch ‘main’ did not follow this step git clone https://github.com/richard-porteous/my-app.git If you look at the repository this step was on branch sprites-example You can skip if you want! we get back to doing it later. This is a little ambitious. Currently we are just experimenting. Soon we will make a few choices and make a simple game. Then we will refactor, and build another game. The first game I think will be a top down and the next from the side likely a platform game.

item.title: Our first pygame - Refactoring - part 4
item.description: if you look at the git repository we are near the post 4 tag. if things dont look the same don’t worry too much. I’d like to make a small change. I want to put the image path in a variable, for now, img_path is a good name #Somewhere near the top of our code we will place the following img_path = 'images/' #Then we replace our existing player load image code with the following concatenation player = pygame.

item.title: Our first pygame - moving images - part 3
item.description: Now we get to play a little. Lets simply draw a simple background and then download some premade shapes that we can move around. First head over to kenney.nl and get the following images to follow along. The files we want are in the png/default folder. The larger images are 80x80. If you are adventurous try other images. I’m going to use individual 2d png files for each item to start.

item.title: Our first pygame - part 2
item.description: All Pygame games share some code in common. Setup, game-loop, user-input, audio etc. etc. We will start building the common code while creating a game and we will refactor it into something reusable as we go. I’m using VSCode with the python and the Git Graph plugin. (pylance is included with the python plugin). It makes editing the code simpler to use an IDE. If you prefer to use another go ahead.

item.title: Our first pygame - part 1
item.description: Refer to Using Python to get python installed and set up a virtial environment. If python is installed Create a folder named mygame create a virtual environment inside activate the virtual environment run this command python3 -m pip install pygame or python3 -m pip install -U pygame --user see getting started anyway now we have our folder, environment, and pygame type $ python >> import pygame dont type the $ or the » if you have no errors you can quit

item.title: Using python
item.description: Do you already have python? I have used cmd on windows, you can use whatever terminal you know how to open. A shortcut on windows is to use explorer to go to the folder you want and type cmd in the bar above. Windows - python, py commands should work Linux/Mac python or python3 should work run the following: python --version if the response is not python 3 or higher then i recommend you check the py command or the python3 command

item.title: Resync Windows time with task scheduler
item.description: NOTE: Time sync should be done as little as possible. See the recommendations on the time server sites. i.e. https://www.pool.ntp.org Tired of forcing your time to resync manually? If you dual boot or your computer just doesn’t keep time after it has been shut down for a while, you may be a little frustrated with the default setting for windows. Linux when booted will set the system time clock to UTC and display your local time.

item.title: Using Git
item.description: It is highly recommended that you use GIT to keep track of your changes and prevent loss of your work. What we will do this Lesson Learn to add your project to a git repository. Know how to use a free online host. git-gui, Sourcetree, etc Git is simple to learn. We use the terminal here, though a Git Client (UI) can help visualize better. I use GitHub as my remote host, but choose whichever you think is best.

item.title: Refactoring - Winforms using mvc
item.description: This was more to follow along in another book when I started, but take a look it has proven useful to me. This post is dependant on the repository. I like this choice as it can make switching out each form one at a time for WPF a little simpler with old apps, just remember WinForms is designed to work with events, and you may end up fighting the UI.
